conclusion: Determine the length of the arc on AC where light rays from O cannot exit through AB or BC.
ABC is a quarter-circle with radius R, and O is the center of the arc AC. ABCO forms a square with each side of length R.
Refractive index n is 2. Calculate critical angle using Snell's law.
Critical angle θc is 30° using sin θc = 1/n = 1/2.
Consider light ray from O hitting arc AC at point P. Angle of incidence at P determines exit through AB or BC.
Find points on arc AC where angle of incidence is greater than 30° when hitting AB or BC.
Case 1: Light ray hitting AB at point E. Angle of incidence at E must be greater than 30°.
For light to hit AB at E, it must exit arc AC at point F with angle ∠EOF less than 60°.
Case 2: Light ray hitting BC at point G. Angle of incidence at G must be greater than 30°.
For light to hit BC at G, it must exit arc AC at point H with angle ∠GOH less than 60°.
Arc AC is divided into segments by points F and H. Segments where light cannot exit are where ∠EOF or ∠GOH is less than 60°.
Total angle subtended by arc AC is 90°. Length of arc where light cannot exit is 30°.
Length of arc where light cannot directly exit through AB or BC is πR/6.
